WEST AND EAST BLEND ON BALI ISLE, NAEB SAYS
On the Island of Bali, the Western world of imagination and the
Eastern world of reality meet and blend. For Bali has the sound and
fragrance, the beauty and the people of our traditional South Sea Island.
The island is never silent, for the Balinese love music more than anything
else -- except perhaps a cockfight -- and somewhere an orchestra is always
at practice on a xylophone, flutes and stringed instruments.
Such is the setting for "The Coming Out", the second of three
radio programs prepared to offer the listener the experience of living as the
people of Bali live within the framework of their traditional culture. The
three Bali programs will be the final broadcasts in the over-all second
series on "The Ways of Mankind" presented as an adult education project by
the National Association of Educational Broadcasters.
"The Coming Out", written by Walter Newman and produced by
Andrew Allan, will be heard over Radio Station -- (name) -- at -- (time) --
on -- (date).
For the series on Bali, Colin McPhee selected and made available
the recorded music from the Island of Bali and acted as special consultant
on the script. Miss Claire Holt served as consultant. Margaret Mead of
the American Museum of Natural History advised on planning the Bali scripts.
The new broadcast presents the simple story of a young Balinese wife
expecting a child. We must push beyond the pageant of tropical market and
stone temple and examine the Bali of every-day life, we are advised in an
introductory narrative by Dr. Walter Goldschmidt, anthropologist of the
University of California, who supervised the "Ways of Mankind" series.
"To the Balinese", Dr. Goldschmidt says, "this island is no exotic
place, but the very center of the world. People are born and die, families
live their lives within walled compounds, men go the rice fields to work, share
for share with th4ir neighbors,, they propitiate gods and ward off evil; they
love, they fear, they hope, they cherish. Now we learn just what they feel
and how they express these feelings."
